description.narrative: Core funding to Ecpat International working to protect children from child prostitution, child pornography and traffickng for sexual purposes.

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The Results Based Framework put forward in 2012 (start of the agreement period) demonstrated ECPAT Secretariat’s approach towards building a network and supporting the collective efforts of the ECPAT movement. A further change in organisational planning was implemented in 2013-2014 in response to the growing organisation and to align work planning and monitoring with the changing organisational and accountability structure. The work planning system focuses on programmes and regions with integrated targeted results towards the overall organisational objectives. This was further adjusted based on the adoption by the ECPAT Network during the International Assembly in December 2014 of a common Strategic Framework that would guide the work of ECPAT members and ECPAT International alike from 2015 till 2018.
Hence, the current, 2016, ECPAT annual report follows this new structure. The key intervention objectives and indicators has been adjusted to reflect the new framework (also adjusted in Trac). ECPAT overall objective is to eliminate the sexual exploitation of children. To achieve this it has elaborated four change goals: The four Change Goals of the Strategic Framework are: 1. Put Children’s voices at the heart of the ECPAT Network 2. Develop the ECPAT Network (more countries, higher capability) 3. Convene, broker and lead cutting-edge research, knowledge creation, and dissemination 4. Build a Global Campaign to end CSEC
During the reporting period 2016 ECPAT has made continued progress towards its change goals. Here is a short summary of results related to the intended outcome:
Organisation of the first Global Survivor Forum on the 18th of November in Strasbourg at the Council of Europe, on the occasion of the European Day against the Sexual Abuse and Exploitation of Children. Twenty-seven local preparatory consultations with over 300 survivors were held to help identify the Forum’s key themes and agenda. This resulted in sharing of experiences and key recommendations on a European level. - Launch of the Bill of Rights at the Child Helplines International Assembly and at the Global Survivor Forum, with plans for wider dissemination during 2017. The Bill of Rights was developed in consultation with over 400 children and youth, the majority of them survivors of sexual exploitation of children. - Following the launch of the Global Study on the Sexual Exploitation of Children in Travel and Tourism in May 2016, more than 20 presentations were delivered in different forums on the Global Study’s findings, in cooperation with UN WTO, ACERWC, OAS/IIN, GARA, SAIEVAC, ISPCAN, INTERPOL, the Global Child Forum and ECPAT member organisations. - Commemoration of the 20th Anniversary of the First World Congress against Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children hosted by the Government of Sweden in August 1996, through a week long active social media campaign by ECPAT member organisation across all regions, raising awareness of Sexual Exploitation of Children. - A large number of CSOs and partners reached through capacity building efforts and technical support to address sexual exploitation of children, especially SECTT and SECO.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
